questions.question: [ Question text, preserving relevant sentiment and context and removing filler words]
questions.answer_summary: [Concise, factual summary including exact metrics, context, products, tools, business drivers, forward-looking metrics, and sentiment]

metadata.raw_response:
ParsedResponse[SummarizeOutputFormat](id='resp_68b3334e03248195953f74d60531c80605fd7440e3da900d', created_at=1756574542.0, error=None, incomplete_details=None, instructions='You are a senior equity analyst with exceptional skills in summarization and thematic analysis. Your goal is to process the Q&A section of an earnings and produce a concise, relevant, and complete summary for hedge fund analysts.

##Instructions
### 1.List each analyst's turn to speak.

-For each, identify all sub-questions and group related questions into a single logical block.

-Create a new "Question" object only for a completely  distinct topic.

###2.Preserve Analyst Context & Sentiment.

-Omit filler phrases (e.g., "My question is for…"), but keep any words that show sentiment or frame the topic (e.g., "Congrats on…").

-Include implicit questions (e.g., requests for explanation without a question mark).

-Paste the exact wording of any reference to investors' questions or financial results and KPIs in the question, even if it was already mentioned by other analysts

###3.Answer Summary Requirements:
For each question or sub-question, summarize the executive's answer so it includes:

-All relevant metrics exactly as stated, with their specific product/service and period (e.g., "up to 80% improvement in email conversion rates" instead of "up to 80% improvement").

-All key contextual details that make the metric or statement understandable without the transcript.

-Explicit naming of specific tools, models, features, or products mentioned.

-The underlying business driver if stated (e.g., "monetization of CRM through core seats" instead of just "seat expansion").

-Any forward-looking metrics or milestones mentioned (e.g., "expecting 50% to 60% of existing customer MRR to go through first renewal by end of 2025").

-The sentiment **only if** explicitly conveyed (e.g., cautious, confident, enthusiastic).
-Flag when the executive does not directly answer the question
-Specify the abbreviation of the **role** of the executive that talked.Example: 'CFO said...'. Bad example: 'CFO (CFO) said','Chief Financial Officer said', '[executive name] said'

###4.Fundamental Rules

-Single source only: Use only the provided transcript between <START TRANSCRIPT> and <END TRANSCRIPT>. If empty, answer "No transcript provided."
-Full coverage: Include every question and answer segment; no material omissions.
-Exact data: No rounding, renaming, or paraphrasing metrics.
-Logical grouping: Related sub-questions from the same analyst grouped together, unrelated ones separate.
-Context with conciseness: Short but with enough background for standalone understanding.
-Guidance & outlook: Always mark and separate forward-looking statements, risks, and opportunities.

###5.Output Structure
Output your response as valid JSON following this exact structure:

```json
{"title": "[Company name] [Quarter, date if available]", "questions_answers": [{"name": "[Analyst Name]", "firm": "[Firm]", "questions": [{"question": "[ Question text, preserving relevant sentiment and context and removing filler words]", "answer_summary": "[Concise, factual summary including exact metrics, context, products, tools, business drivers, forward-looking metrics, and sentiment]"}]}]}
```

IMPORTANT: 
- Output ONLY valid JSON, no additional text or markdown formatting

Wait for the transcript that will be sent inside <START TRANSCRIPT> and <END TRANSCRIPT>', metadata={}, model='gpt-5-2025-08-07', object='response', output=[ResponseReasoningItem(id='rs_68b3334f045481958f683e279eb6387005fd7440e3da900d', summary=[], type='reasoning', content=None, encrypted_content=None, status=None), ParsedResponseOutputMessage[SummarizeOutputFormat](id='msg_68b3334f4f9081958fbf246a2fab0c3c05fd7440e3da900d', content=[ParsedResponseOutputText[SummarizeOutputFormat](annotations=[], text='{"title":"Atlassian Q4 2025 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2025","analysts":[{"name":"Keith Weiss","firm":"Morgan Stanley","questions":[{"question":"Congratulations on a really strong end to the year. Walk through what you’re seeing in the business today around seat expansion with developers or more broadly. What’s likely to transpire going forward as AI code-generation tools change developer roles, and how will these innovations affect Atlassian’s core business?","answer_summary":"CEO said they are not seeing any impact from AI code-generation on expansion rates, growth rates, or adoption rates of technical products; usage and user growth remain healthy. Early data shows customers that connect code-generation tools see business users in those Jira instances growing faster than customers without those tools, reinforcing Jira as the center of gravity for work. CEO believes there will be more developers and more people across functions creating software in 5 years, more software overall, and more need to manage it, expanding Atlassian’s opportunity. Internally, Atlassian uses Rovo Dev on top of SWE-bench, plus 3–4 code-generation tools at >1,000 users each, boosting speed and output, while continuing to hire engineers. AI is viewed as a huge tailwind. Tools and platforms cited: Jira, Rovo Dev, SWE-bench. Sentiment: confident."}]},{"name":"Alex Mulan (for Brent Thill)","firm":"Jefferies","questions":[{"question":"Free cash flow came in broadly flat versus last year around $1.5 billion. How should we think about the trajectory for free cash flow in 2026?","answer_summary":"CFO said Q4 free cash flow was $360 million, down 13% year-over-year, primarily due to strong prior-year collections tied to server/support dynamics; results were in line with expectations. Near-term temporal headwinds include shifting multiyear agreements from upfront to annual billing and more backloaded sales as enterprise cloud grows; accounting for this, cash flow reflected strong quarterly performance. Longer term, free cash flow will correlate with non-GAAP operating income trends; short-term differences are timing-related (e.g., Q1 bonus payout). Over time, expect about a 500 basis point difference between non-GAAP operating margin and free cash flow margin, with plus/minus variation; this remains the expectation for FY ’26 and beyond. Forward-looking: FCF margin ~500 bps below non-GAAP op margin over time."}]},{"name":"Kash Rangan","firm":"Goldman Sachs","questions":[{"question":"To maintain your longer-term growth guidance, fiscal ’27 seems to imply acceleration from fiscal ’26. What potential inflection points and levers (go-to-market tweaks, enterprise flex, server/Data Center-to-Cloud transition) can drive that acceleration?","answer_summary":"CFO said FY ’26 guidance approach is unchanged from FY ’25: conservative and risk-adjusted for macro uncertainty and potential disruption from evolving the enterprise go-to-market motion. No change to outlook to deliver 20% compounded annual growth from FY ’24 through FY ’27; 20% growth in FY ’25 lays a strong foundation. Growth levers: paid seat expansion, cross-sell, upsell, pricing, new customer growth; AI expands opportunity given cloud platform position and Teamwork Graph plus R&D investment. CEO reiterated confidence in long-term revenue and margin targets; highlighted strong Teamwork Collection momentum in first 3 months. Cited customer wins: a global automotive manufacturer (high tens of thousands of users) adopting Teamwork Collection and Strategy Collection, with AI integration a core reason; a leading chip company migrating tens of thousands of users from Data Center to Cloud, consolidating onto Atlassian, citing AI, third-party integrations, Rovo search, and Rovo chat. Forward-looking: reaffirmed 20% CAGR FY ’24–FY ’27; enterprise AI, System of Work, and Teamwork Collection as key drivers. Sentiment: confident."}]},{"name":"Michael Turrin","firm":"Wells Fargo","questions":[{"question":"Expand on the FY ’26 framework around Enterprise go-to-market. Compare how FY ’25 closed relative to the execution risk embedded in guidance. RPO and bookings look supportive—how did the year close vs. forecast and initial FY ’26 guide?","answer_summary":"CFO said execution by sales and partners drove very strong bookings and billings. RPO reached $3.3 billion, up 38% year-over-year; roughly 74% to be recognized in the next 12 months, up 29% year-over-year; the remaining portion increased 71% driven by large cloud multiyear agreements—signaling customer commitment and confidence. Record number of $1 million+ deals; Data Center-to-Cloud migrations up 60% year-over-year; strong Teamwork Collection momentum. Revenue exceeded expectations: Cloud and marketplace outperformed, Data Center in line. Assumed negative impact on paid seat expansion and migrations in guidance did not fully materialize; macro and business trends remained relatively stable. Q4 Cloud outperformance drivers: paid seat expansion, cross-sell, migrations; other cloud drivers in line. Data Center growth driven by pricing, partially offset by cloud migrations; benefited from several large renewals. Marketplace outperformance driven by third-party app sales from Data Center. Steady performance across products, segments, regions. Sentiment: confident."}]},{"name":"Arsenije Edward Matovic (for Alex Zukin)","firm":"Wolfe Research","questions":[{"question":"Given strong Teamwork Collection traction and increased R&D focus next year, can we expect more AI capabilities or new feature launches within the collection this year to drive momentum?","answer_summary":"CEO said yes—expect new capabilities. AI is a huge tailwind; Atlassian continues to innovate with AI embedded in the core cloud platform and Teamwork Graph. Metrics cited: net expansion rate of 120%; AI users reached 2.3 million (up from 1.5 million last quarter); token usage up 5x quarter-on-quarter. Examples: Rovo Dev CLI launched; MCP servers in beta; working with Anthropic; continuing to work with OpenAI on GPT-5. Confluence impact: users who use editor AI create 15% more pages and make 33% more edits than before. Forward-looking: more AI capabilities shipping; continued platform-led differentiation."},{"question":"Help us understand the mid-single-digit migration contribution in Cloud guidance. How did FY ’25 migration contribution pan out versus last year’s expectations, and why the conservatism for FY ’26 mid-single-digit contribution?","answer_summary":"CFO said FY ’25 migrations contributed in the mid- to high single-digit range to Cloud revenue growth, helped by prior-year server/support-related migrations. Strong Q4 and FY ’25 on migrations driven by investments in customer success and forward-deployed engineering (e.g., Fast shift) and by R&D adding automation, analytics, and AI to the Cloud platform and apps. For FY ’26, guidance assumes a sequentially lower mid-single-digit contribution due to macro and enterprise go-to-market evolution risks and the complexity of remaining Data Center migrations (largest, most complex customers; hybrid approaches; quarter-to-quarter variability). Longer term, expect migrations to contribute mid- to high single digits to Cloud revenue growth over the next 2 to 3 years. Forward-looking: migration contribution mid- to high single digits over 2–3 years; FY ’26 mid-single-digit assumption is conservative."}]},{"name":"Arjun Bhatia","firm":"William Blair","questions":[{"question":"Enterprise was very strong with $1 million+ ACV deals. With Brian on board, how are you changing go-to-market to continue Enterprise acceleration? Is this done in ’26 or a multiyear journey into ’27?","answer_summary":"CEO said Atlassian already has a robust enterprise business with hundreds of customers north of $1 million run rate and a fantastic quarter for $1 million deals. Enterprise transformation is ongoing over the next 1–3 years, not a one-year fix. Brian Duffy (6 months in) is improving the sales transformation. TAM context: ~$14 billion addressable market revenue opportunity within the existing customer base alone, without pricing changes; over 80% of the Fortune 500 are customers but represent ~10% of business—implying large expansion potential. Data Center-to-Cloud migrations up 60% year-over-year, skewing to largest customers. Announced Google Cloud partnership as a multi-cloud milestone improving resilience. Strong Teamwork Collection wins ahead of expectations. Focus areas: more customer-centric processes; deeper partnerships; improved customer success; continued sales execution and operations upgrades; stronger partner ecosystem and GSIs; and sales culture. Sentiment: bullish."}]},{"name":"Karl Keirstead","firm":"UBS","questions":[{"question":"Q1 Data Center growth guide is a reasonably large step down. Anything unique about the September quarter driving caution?","answer_summary":"CFO said Q1 Data Center guidance is approximately 8%, a step down from Q4. Drivers: Q4 benefited from several large renewals and has a much bigger expiration base than Q1; Q1 is seasonally weaker with less opportunity for expansion and price increases. Q4 growth was driven primarily by pricing and partially offset by Cloud migrations. Additional Q1 headwinds: shift to 1-year deal terms from a programmatic change a year ago; beginning to lap prior server/support migration benefits. Primary factor is smaller expiration base in Q1."}]},{"name":"Gregg Moskowitz","firm":"Mizuho","questions":[{"question":"It’s easier said than done to drive more wall-to-wall deployments. With about half of licensees in nontechnical roles but lower penetration vs technical employees, how do you convince more Global 2000 to equip every salesperson and every finance, HR, marketing and legal professional with an Atlassian license?","answer_summary":"CEO said consolidation momentum is strong and accelerating; consolidation is a competitive weapon. Business user segment growth has accelerated and is a major opportunity. Drivers: Teamwork Collection broadens offering by separating software from broad collaboration pieces; ongoing investments in design, speed, performance, and Jira usability for business teams; Loom adoption in sales and outbound communication expands Atlassian footprint; Trello remains strong with broad users; Rovo (search/chat/agents) with connectors enabling business teams to run workflows across Atlassian and third-party tools. Business team usage and technology team usage are both growing; not one at the expense of the other. Sentiment: confident."}]},{"name":"DJ Hynes","firm":"Canaccord Genuity","questions":[{"question":"How should we think about the bridge from MAU growth in Rovo to more robust monetization and timing? Will it show up first in consumption/usage or more effective cross-sell?","answer_summary":"CFO said strategy prioritizes deployment, usage, and engagement for Rovo; monetization is secondary and longer-term. FY ’26 plan includes some consumption-based Rovo revenue, but guidance assumes very nominal amounts due to limits set to incent adoption. Expect broader benefits over time: seat expansion, upgrades to higher editions, and migrations. Seeing strong premium and enterprise edition uptake, partly due to AI/Rovo value. CEO added: Teamwork Collection uplift across seats is partially AI-driven; there is a SKU for non-Atlassian users to access Rovo search/chat as a stepping stone, though preference is to move them into Teamwork Collection. Increasing use of consumption pricing in Forge, Bitbucket pipelines, JSM virtual service agents and assets, and AI credits; Teamwork Collection includes a larger set of AI credits to drive usage while managing margin. Metrics: token usage up 5x quarter-on-quarter; AI tools growth rate ~50%-ish; premium and enterprise editions growth rate about 40% year-over-year. Rovo Dev and Rovo Dev CLI are unmonetized to drive usage first. Forward-looking: monetization later via consumption and cross-sell/upsell as usage scales. Sentiment: enthusiastic about uptake."}]},{"name":"Jason Celino","firm":"KeyBanc Capital Markets","questions":[{"question":"Operating margin guidance is 24%, a modest compression vs 2025 and close to the mid-20s 2027 target. What are the investment priorities this year, including plans to expand sales count for service management, and how might that ramp?","answer_summary":"CFO said operating expenses will grow at largely consistent rates FY ’25 to FY ’26, with investment primarily in sales and marketing and R&D aligned to Enterprise, Cloud AI, and System of Work. Operating margin guidance is 24%, slightly lower than FY ’25, reflecting conservative, risk-adjusted revenue guidance; relatively stable gross margins as cloud infrastructure/support optimization offsets greater cloud mix and rising AI usage costs; and ongoing investments. Framework: manage costs carefully, invest in highest-return opportunities, and meet profitability commitments; sometimes invest upside, other times allow revenue/gross margin outperformance to drop to bottom line. Confident in achieving FY ’27 non-GAAP operating margin target in excess of 25%. CEO added sales hiring was ahead of target in the quarter, reflecting strong talent pipeline and execution; supports enterprise momentum. Reiterated commitment to FY ’27 25% margin target while investing to win in AI; expects FY ’25 discipline to continue in FY ’26. Forward-looking: maintain discipline to hit >25% FY ’27 non-GAAP operating margin while investing in AI and enterprise sales capacity."}]}]}', type='output_text', logprobs=[], parsed=SummarizeOutputFormat(title='Atlassian Q4 2025 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2025', analysts=[AnalystQA(name='Keith Weiss', firm='Morgan Stanley', questions=[Question(question='Congratulations on a really strong end to the year. questions.question: Congratulations on a really strong end to the year. Walk through what you’re seeing in the business today around seat expansion with developers or more broadly. What’s likely to transpire going forward as AI code-generation tools change developer roles, and how will these innovations affect Atlassian’s core business?
questions.answer_summary: CEO said they are not seeing any impact from AI code-generation on expansion rates, growth rates, or adoption rates of technical products; usage and user growth remain healthy. Early data shows customers that connect code-generation tools see business users in those Jira instances growing faster than customers without those tools, reinforcing Jira as the center of gravity for work. CEO believes there will be more developers and more people across functions creating software in 5 years, more software overall, and more need to manage it, expanding Atlassian’s opportunity. Internally, Atlassian uses Rovo Dev on top of SWE-bench, plus 3–4 code-generation tools at >1,000 users each, boosting speed and output, while continuing to hire engineers. AI is viewed as a huge tailwind. Tools and platforms cited: Jira, Rovo Dev, SWE-bench. Sentiment: confident.

questions.question: Free cash flow came in broadly flat versus last year around $1.5 billion. How should we think about the trajectory for free cash flow in 2026?
questions.answer_summary: CFO said Q4 free cash flow was $360 million, down 13% year-over-year, primarily due to strong prior-year collections tied to server/support dynamics; results were in line with expectations. Near-term temporal headwinds include shifting multiyear agreements from upfront to annual billing and more backloaded sales as enterprise cloud grows; accounting for this, cash flow reflected strong quarterly performance. Longer term, free cash flow will correlate with non-GAAP operating income trends; short-term differences are timing-related (e.g., Q1 bonus payout). Over time, expect about a 500 basis point difference between non-GAAP operating margin and free cash flow margin, with plus/minus variation; this remains the expectation for FY ’26 and beyond. Forward-looking: FCF margin ~500 bps below non-GAAP op margin over time.

questions.question: To maintain your longer-term growth guidance, fiscal ’27 seems to imply acceleration from fiscal ’26. What potential inflection points and levers (go-to-market tweaks, enterprise flex, server/Data Center-to-Cloud transition) can drive that acceleration?
questions.answer_summary: CFO said FY ’26 guidance approach is unchanged from FY ’25: conservative and risk-adjusted for macro uncertainty and potential disruption from evolving the enterprise go-to-market motion. No change to outlook to deliver 20% compounded annual growth from FY ’24 through FY ’27; 20% growth in FY ’25 lays a strong foundation. Growth levers: paid seat expansion, cross-sell, upsell, pricing, new customer growth; AI expands opportunity given cloud platform position and Teamwork Graph plus R&D investment. CEO reiterated confidence in long-term revenue and margin targets; highlighted strong Teamwork Collection momentum in first 3 months. Cited customer wins: a global automotive manufacturer (high tens of thousands of users) adopting Teamwork Collection and Strategy Collection, with AI integration a core reason; a leading chip company migrating tens of thousands of users from Data Center to Cloud, consolidating onto Atlassian, citing AI, third-party integrations, Rovo search, and Rovo chat. Forward-looking: reaffirmed 20% CAGR FY ’24–FY ’27; enterprise AI, System of Work, and Teamwork Collection as key drivers. Sentiment: confident.

questions.question: Expand on the FY ’26 framework around Enterprise go-to-market. Compare how FY ’25 closed relative to the execution risk embedded in guidance. RPO and bookings look supportive—how did the year close vs. forecast and initial FY ’26 guide?
questions.answer_summary: CFO said execution by sales and partners drove very strong bookings and billings. RPO reached $3.3 billion, up 38% year-over-year; roughly 74% to be recognized in the next 12 months, up 29% year-over-year; the remaining portion increased 71% driven by large cloud multiyear agreements—signaling customer commitment and confidence. Record number of $1 million+ deals; Data Center-to-Cloud migrations up 60% year-over-year; strong Teamwork Collection momentum. Revenue exceeded expectations: Cloud and marketplace outperformed, Data Center in line. Assumed negative impact on paid seat expansion and migrations in guidance did not fully materialize; macro and business trends remained relatively stable. Q4 Cloud outperformance drivers: paid seat expansion, cross-sell, migrations; other cloud drivers in line. Data Center growth driven by pricing, partially offset by cloud migrations; benefited from several large renewals. Marketplace outperformance driven by third-party app sales from Data Center. Steady performance across products, segments, regions. Sentiment: confident.

questions.question: Given strong Teamwork Collection traction and increased R&D focus next year, can we expect more AI capabilities or new feature launches within the collection this year to drive momentum?
questions.answer_summary: CEO said yes—expect new capabilities. AI is a huge tailwind; Atlassian continues to innovate with AI embedded in the core cloud platform and Teamwork Graph. Metrics cited: net expansion rate of 120%; AI users reached 2.3 million (up from 1.5 million last quarter); token usage up 5x quarter-on-quarter. Examples: Rovo Dev CLI launched; MCP servers in beta; working with Anthropic; continuing to work with OpenAI on GPT-5. Confluence impact: users who use editor AI create 15% more pages and make 33% more edits than before. Forward-looking: more AI capabilities shipping; continued platform-led differentiation.

questions.question: Help us understand the mid-single-digit migration contribution in Cloud guidance. How did FY ’25 migration contribution pan out versus last year’s expectations, and why the conservatism for FY ’26 mid-single-digit contribution?
questions.answer_summary: CFO said FY ’25 migrations contributed in the mid- to high single-digit range to Cloud revenue growth, helped by prior-year server/support-related migrations. Strong Q4 and FY ’25 on migrations driven by investments in customer success and forward-deployed engineering (e.g., Fast shift) and by R&D adding automation, analytics, and AI to the Cloud platform and apps. For FY ’26, guidance assumes a sequentially lower mid-single-digit contribution due to macro and enterprise go-to-market evolution risks and the complexity of remaining Data Center migrations (largest, most complex customers; hybrid approaches; quarter-to-quarter variability). Longer term, expect migrations to contribute mid- to high single digits to Cloud revenue growth over the next 2 to 3 years. Forward-looking: migration contribution mid- to high single digits over 2–3 years; FY ’26 mid-single-digit assumption is conservative.

questions.question: Enterprise was very strong with $1 million+ ACV deals. With Brian on board, how are you changing go-to-market to continue Enterprise acceleration? Is this done in ’26 or a multiyear journey into ’27?
questions.answer_summary: CEO said Atlassian already has a robust enterprise business with hundreds of customers north of $1 million run rate and a fantastic quarter for $1 million deals. Enterprise transformation is ongoing over the next 1–3 years, not a one-year fix. Brian Duffy (6 months in) is improving the sales transformation. TAM context: ~$14 billion addressable market revenue opportunity within the existing customer base alone, without pricing changes; over 80% of the Fortune 500 are customers but represent ~10% of business—implying large expansion potential. Data Center-to-Cloud migrations up 60% year-over-year, skewing to largest customers. Announced Google Cloud partnership as a multi-cloud milestone improving resilience. Strong Teamwork Collection wins ahead of expectations. Focus areas: more customer-centric processes; deeper partnerships; improved customer success; continued sales execution and operations upgrades; stronger partner ecosystem and GSIs; and sales culture. Sentiment: bullish.

questions.question: Q1 Data Center growth guide is a reasonably large step down. Anything unique about the September quarter driving caution?
questions.answer_summary: CFO said Q1 Data Center guidance is approximately 8%, a step down from Q4. Drivers: Q4 benefited from several large renewals and has a much bigger expiration base than Q1; Q1 is seasonally weaker with less opportunity for expansion and price increases. Q4 growth was driven primarily by pricing and partially offset by Cloud migrations. Additional Q1 headwinds: shift to 1-year deal terms from a programmatic change a year ago; beginning to lap prior server/support migration benefits. Primary factor is smaller expiration base in Q1.

questions.question: It’s easier said than done to drive more wall-to-wall deployments. With about half of licensees in nontechnical roles but lower penetration vs technical employees, how do you convince more Global 2000 to equip every salesperson and every finance, HR, marketing and legal professional with an Atlassian license?
questions.answer_summary: CEO said consolidation momentum is strong and accelerating; consolidation is a competitive weapon. Business user segment growth has accelerated and is a major opportunity. Drivers: Teamwork Collection broadens offering by separating software from broad collaboration pieces; ongoing investments in design, speed, performance, and Jira usability for business teams; Loom adoption in sales and outbound communication expands Atlassian footprint; Trello remains strong with broad users; Rovo (search/chat/agents) with connectors enabling business teams to run workflows across Atlassian and third-party tools. Business team usage and technology team usage are both growing; not one at the expense of the other. Sentiment: confident.

questions.question: How should we think about the bridge from MAU growth in Rovo to more robust monetization and timing? Will it show up first in consumption/usage or more effective cross-sell?
questions.answer_summary: CFO said strategy prioritizes deployment, usage, and engagement for Rovo; monetization is secondary and longer-term. FY ’26 plan includes some consumption-based Rovo revenue, but guidance assumes very nominal amounts due to limits set to incent adoption. Expect broader benefits over time: seat expansion, upgrades to higher editions, and migrations. Seeing strong premium and enterprise edition uptake, partly due to AI/Rovo value. CEO added: Teamwork Collection uplift across seats is partially AI-driven; there is a SKU for non-Atlassian users to access Rovo search/chat as a stepping stone, though preference is to move them into Teamwork Collection. Increasing use of consumption pricing in Forge, Bitbucket pipelines, JSM virtual service agents and assets, and AI credits; Teamwork Collection includes a larger set of AI credits to drive usage while managing margin. Metrics: token usage up 5x quarter-on-quarter; AI tools growth rate ~50%-ish; premium and enterprise editions growth rate about 40% year-over-year. Rovo Dev and Rovo Dev CLI are unmonetized to drive usage first. Forward-looking: monetization later via consumption and cross-sell/upsell as usage scales. Sentiment: enthusiastic about uptake.

questions.question: Operating margin guidance is 24%, a modest compression vs 2025 and close to the mid-20s 2027 target. What are the investment priorities this year, including plans to expand sales count for service management, and how might that ramp?
questions.answer_summary: CFO said operating expenses will grow at largely consistent rates FY ’25 to FY ’26, with investment primarily in sales and marketing and R&D aligned to Enterprise, Cloud AI, and System of Work. Operating margin guidance is 24%, slightly lower than FY ’25, reflecting conservative, risk-adjusted revenue guidance; relatively stable gross margins as cloud infrastructure/support optimization offsets greater cloud mix and rising AI usage costs; and ongoing investments. Framework: manage costs carefully, invest in highest-return opportunities, and meet profitability commitments; sometimes invest upside, other times allow revenue/gross margin outperformance to drop to bottom line. Confident in achieving FY ’27 non-GAAP operating margin target in excess of 25%. CEO added sales hiring was ahead of target in the quarter, reflecting strong talent pipeline and execution; supports enterprise momentum. Reiterated commitment to FY ’27 25% margin target while investing to win in AI; expects FY ’25 discipline to continue in FY ’26. Forward-looking: maintain discipline to hit >25% FY ’27 non-GAAP operating margin while investing in AI and enterprise sales capacity.
